citations.narrative:
There were 3 empty animal enclosures along the inside of the northern perimeter fence which were all approximately one
foot away from the perimeter fence and have reduced its effective height. One of these enclosures was approximately 6
feet in height. Enclosures, structures or other items located or stored next to the perimeter fence reduces its effective
height and may facilitate animal escape. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals and ensures that
unauthorized persons or animals cannot access the facility, to prevent physical contact between animals inside the
primary enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence, and to effectively function as a secondary
containment system in case of animal escape.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 11/22/2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
KATHLEEN GARLAND, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist n

narrative:
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There were 3 empty animal enclosures along the inside of the northern perimeter fence which were all approximately one 
foot away from the perimeter fence and have reduced its effective height. One of these enclosures was approximately 6 
feet in height. Enclosures, structures or other items located or stored next to the perimeter fence reduces its effective 
height and may facilitate animal escape. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals and ensures that 
unauthorized persons or animals cannot access the facility, to prevent physical contact between animals inside the 
primary enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence, and to effectively function as a secondary 
containment system in case of animal escape. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 11/22/2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
KATHLEEN GARLAND, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist n
